facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 467 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 467 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated February 1961 of Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 837 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated February 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 837 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 13, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 13, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-

facts.text: Appellants are the illegitimate son and daughter of Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the illegitimate son and daughter of one Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur.

facts.text: Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur sold 18 bighas, 1 biswas and 5-1/2 biswansis of agricultural land for Rs. 10,000/- to the respondents by registered deed dated December 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed of sale dated December 1, 1956 the said lady sold 18 bighas, 1 biswas and 5-1/2 biswansis of agricultural land for a sum of Rs. 10,000/- to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellants filed a suit to pre-empt the sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a suit to pre-empt this sale.

facts.text: There was some dispute about the consideration actually paid.

anchor.surface_text: There was some dispute about the companysideration actually paid but we are number number companycerned with it.

facts.text: Trial court granted decree for pre-emption to appellants, though to a limited extent.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial companyrt as well as the District Court on appeal granted to the appellants a decree for pre- emption, though to a limited extent.

facts.text: District Court on appeal granted decree for pre-emption to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial companyrt as well as the District Court on appeal granted to the appellants a decree for pre- emption, though to a limited extent.

facts.text: Respondents filed second appeal to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed a second appeal to the High Court and the learned Judges, by the judgment number under appeal,

facts.text: Punjab High Court directed dismissal of the suit on ground that appellants not entitled under s.15(2)(b) of Punjab Pre-emption Act as amended.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges, by the judgment number under appeal, directed the dismissal of the suit on the ground that the appellants were number companyprehended within the class of persons who were entitled to pre-emption under s. 15 2  b  of the Punjab Pre-emption Act as it number stands under the amendment effected by Act X of 1960.

facts.text: Present appeal brought by special leave from High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It is from this judgment that, by special leave, the present appeal has been brought.

facts.text: Appellants' counsel submitted that s.15 must be read with Hindu Succession Act, 1956, entitling illegitimate children to succeed.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain-learned Counsel for the appellants submitted to us that the provision in s. 15 of the Pre- emption Act must be read in companyjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 which made provision for the devolution of property belonging to a female owner and that as under the latter enactment illegitimate children of a Hindu female were entitled to succeed to her property,
We are unable to accept this submission of learned Counsel.

facts.text: Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 amended by Act X of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain-learned Counsel for the appellants submitted to us that the provision in s. 15 of the Pre- emption Act must be read in companyjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 which made provision for the devolution of property belonging to a female owner and that as under the latter enactment illegitimate children of a Hindu female were entitled to succeed to her property,
Take, for instance, the case where a female succeeds to property through her father or brother dealt with in s. 15 2  a  of the Pre-emption Act.

issues.text: Do the words son or daughter of such female occurring in s. 15(2)(b) of the Punjab Preemption Act, 1913 as amended by Act X of 1960 include an illegitimate son or illegitimate daughter of such female?

anchor.surface_text: Do the words son or daughter of such female occurring in s. 15 2  b  of the Punjab Preemption Act, 1913 as amended by Act X of 1960 include an illegitimate son or illegitimate daughter of such female

issues.text: Whether the provision in s. 15 of the Pre-emption Act must be read in conjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 such that son or daughter includes illegitimate children entitled to succeed under the latter?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain-learned Counsel for the appellants submitted to us that the provision in s. 15 of the Pre- emption Act must be read in companyjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 which made provision for the devolution of property belonging to a female owner and that as under the latter enactment illegitimate children of a Hindu female were entitled to succeed to her property,

issues.text: Whether, absent express provision, the context of s. 15 indicates that son or daughter includes illegitimate children denoting blood relationship apart from legitimacy?

anchor.surface_text: That the numbermal rule of companystruction of the words child, son or daughter occurring in a statute would include only legitimate children i.e., born in wedlock, is too elementary to require authority. No doubt, there might be express provision in the statute itself to give these words a more extended meaning as to include also illegitimate children and s. 3 j  of the Hindu Succession Act  Act XXX of 1956  furnishes a good illustration of such a provision.

issues.text: Whether the words son or daughter in s. 15 bear the same meaning (legitimate only) as applied to male vendors and female vendors?

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the words son or daughter occur more than once in that section. It was fairly companyceded by Mr. Bishan Narain that where the son or daughter of a male vendor is referred to, as in s. 15 1 . the words mean only the legitimate issue of the vendor. If so, it cannot be that in the case of a female vendor the words companyld have a different companynotation.

issues.text: Whether the statutory right of pre-emption under s. 15 is to be construed depending on the personal law of succession applicable to the vendor (e.g., Hindu vs. Christian)?

anchor.surface_text: As it is companymon ground that the statutory right of pre-emption companyferred by s. 15 is as much applicable to a Christian owner of property as to a Hindu,

arguments.claim: Provision in s.15 of Pre-emption Act must be read in conjunction with Hindu Succession Act 1956 entitling illegitimate children to succeed, so 'son or daughter' includes illegitimate children

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain-learned Counsel for the appellants submitted to us that the provision in s. 15 of the Pre- emption Act must be read in companyjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 which made provision for the devolution of property belonging to a female owner and that as under the latter enactment illegitimate children of a Hindu female were entitled to succeed to her property, it must be held that when the Punjab legislature used in 1960 the expression son or daughter it meant a son or a daughter who would be entitled to succeed as an heir of a Hindu female.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panystruction calls for companysideration reads a

arguments.court_reasoning: Construction untenable as pre-emption vesting order differs from Hindu Succession Act succession rules, e.g., in s.15(2)(a)

arguments.claim: Appellants not comprehended within class entitled to pre-emption under s.15(2)(b) of Punjab Pre-emption Act

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges, by the judgment number under appeal, directed the dismissal of the suit on the ground that the appellants were number companyprehended within the class of persons who were entitled to pre-emption under s. 15 2  b  of the Punjab Pre-emption Act as it number stands under the amendment effected by Act X of 1960.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees illegitimate children excluded by plain meaning

arguments.claim: Normal rule of construction limits 'son or daughter' in statute to legitimate children born in wedlock

anchor.surface_text: That the numbermal rule of companystruction of the words child, son or daughter occurring in a statute would include only legitimate children i.e., born in wedlock, is too elementary to require authority.

arguments.claim: No express provision or context in Pre-emption Act extends 'son or daughter' to illegitimate children unlike Hindu Succession Act s.3(j)

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, there might be express provision in the statute itself to give these words a more extended meaning as to include also illegitimate children and s. 3 j  of the Hindu Succession Act  Act XXX of 1956  furnishes a good illustration of such a provision. It might even be that without an express provision in that regard the companytext might indicate that the words were used in a more companypre- hensive sense as indicating merely a blood relationship apart from the question of legitimacy.

arguments.claim: 'Son or daughter' bears consistent legitimate-only meaning throughout s.15 including for male and female vendors

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the words son or daughter occur more than once in that section. It was fairly companyceded by Mr. Bishan Narain that where the son or daughter of a male vendor is referred to, as in s. 15 1 . the words mean only the legitimate issue of the vendor. If so, it cannot be that in the case of a female vendor the words companyld have a different companynotation.

arguments.claim: For male vendor in s.15(1), 'son or daughter' means only legitimate issue

anchor.surface_text: It was fairly companyceded by Mr. Bishan Narain that where the son or daughter of a male vendor is referred to, as in s. 15 1 . the words mean only the legitimate issue of the vendor.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of such a provision. It might even be that without an express provision in that regard the companytext might indicate that the words were used in a mo

arguments.claim: Pre-emption right under s.15(2)(a) vests differently from Hindu Succession Act succession for female's property from father/brother

anchor.surface_text: Take, for instance, the case where a female succeeds to property through her father or brother dealt with in s. 15 2  a  of the Pre-emption Act. Her heirs under the Hindu Succession Act would be, if the property was inherited from her father, her son or daughter  including the children of any predeceased son or daughter  and in their absence the heirs of the father.

arguments.claim: Statutory pre-emption right under s.15 applies equally to Hindus and Christians independent of personal succession law

anchor.surface_text: As it is companymon ground that the statutory right of pre-emption companyferred by s. 15 is as much applicable to a Christian owner of property as to a Hindu,

arguments.claim: 'Brother's son' in s.15(2)(a)(i) refers only to legitimate nephew

anchor.surface_text: Even taking the case of a female vendor herself, there is a reference in s. 15 2  a  i  to the brothers son of such vendor. It companyld hardly be open to argument that a brothers illegitimate son is companyprehended within those words.

holdings.text: The words 'son or daughter' in s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Pre-emption Act mean only legitimate son and legitimate daughter, excluding illegitimate children.

anchor.surface_text: The matter appears to us to be too clear for argument that when s. 15 2  b  i  uses the words son or daughter it meant only a legitimate son and a legitimate daughter of the female vendor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal rule of construction limits to legitimate issue; no express extension; consistent usage in section for male vendors and 'brother's son'; context does not indicate blood relation beyond legitimacy.

holdings.text: The provision in s.15 of the Pre-emption Act cannot be read in conjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 to include illegitimate children as heirs.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this submission of learned Counsel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vesting order in pre-emption differs from succession devolution under HSA, e.g., s.15(2)(a) vests in brother not children; cannot import succession rules into pre-emption.

holdings.text: Absent express provision or contextual indication, words 'son or daughter' in a statute include only legitimate children born in wedlock.

anchor.surface_text: That the normal rule of construction of the words child, son or daughter occurring in a statute would include only legitimate children i.e., born in wedlock, is too elementary to require authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elementary rule of construction; HSA s.3(j) illustrates need for express inclusion of illegitimate, absent here; no contextual support for broader blood relation meaning.

holdings.text: The words 'son or daughter' in s.15 bear the same meaning (legitimate issue only) whether referring to male or female vendors.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the words son or daughter occur more than once in that section. It was fairly conceded by Mr. Bishan Narain that where the son or daughter of a male vendor is referred to, as in s. 15 1 . the words mean only the legitimate issue of the vendor. If so, it cannot be that in the case of a female vendor the words could have a different connotation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner concedes legitimate-only for male vendor in s.15(1); same words cannot differ for female vendor; consistent interpretation within statute.

holdings.text: Statutory right of pre-emption under s.15 is not to be construed by reference to the vendor's personal law of succession.

anchor.surface_text: The theory, therefore, that we should resort to the line of heirs as in an intestate succession under the Hindu Succession Act or, for the matter of that, to any other system of Common Law or statute applicable to the vendor is obviously untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-emption applies equally to Hindu or Christian vendors; vesting differs from succession; construction independent of personal law changes or religion.

anchor.surface_text: The matter appears to us to be too clear for argument that when s. 15 2  b  i  uses the words son or daughter it meant only a legitimate son and a legitimate daughter of the female vendor.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants (illegitimate son and daughter) not entitled to pre-emption right under s. 15(2)(b) of Punjab Pre-emption Act; High Court order upheld

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the words son or daughter occur more than once in that section. It was fairly conceded by Mr. Bishan Narain that where the son or daughter of a male vendor is referred to, as in s. 15 1 . the words mean only the legitimate issue of the vendor.
